review: I'm an exceedingly picky person about my technology and did a lot of research before buying the Amazon Fire TV, and I'm very glad that I did. It packs a huge amount of horsepower into a tiny little box at what I consider a very fair price point. (they do go on sale, however!) The single biggest reason I bought this unit was because of it's ability to "sideload" third party applications. This means you can add Android apps which aren't necessarily part of Amazon's store. Why would you want to do that? Well, the amazing little free application, Kodi/XBMC has been ported to android and it works perfectly on the Fire TV. Kodi/XBMC has the slickest interface of any media browser I've yet seen and as an open source project it's infinitely expandable with third party add-ons. What's even better, you can use Kodi to launch other Android apps from its own interface. That means, if you set things up right, you might never even have to look at or use the Amazon GUI. Of course, it's still there and you still have access to everything within it's purview, but you can just as easily take any application you'd access under Amazon Fire OS and create a shortcut for it inside of Kodi.I keep all of my media on a networked attached storage box in my basement. Using Kodi on the Fire TV, I can now play that content through a familiar interface using that singular, shared media resource. This goes for movies, television, pictures, music, etc. Kodi has the added benefit of being able to store its library metadata on a MySql database so every instance of Kodi/XBMC can share s singular library meaning my "previously watched" statuses or items in progress will be synchronized across every "seat" in the house.Another must-have feature for these boxes that only the Fire TV has is the wired ethernet port. Wireless is convenient and works great in many cases, but for streaming 1080p video there's really no substitute for a wired connection if one is available. Wireless has a lot of data irregularities that require re-transmissions of packets. Generally not a problem under typical conditions but when we're getting into heavy bandwidth, low latency, the wired connection becomes much more reliable.All in all, Amazon made a brilliant choice when they let end users side-load their own applications without having to "root" the box. This opens up incredibly powerful opportunities. There are lots of other android based streaming products out there, plenty of them here on Amazon for sale, but the brand reputation and support of the Amazon product with the extensibility of adding third party applications made this one a no-brainer for me. Bonus points because a certain office product retailer tends to offer $25 and $30 off coupons from time to time...and they carry this in their store, but even at MSRP this is a good value.
